Chronic limb threatening ischaemia (CLTI: Patient A, a 65-year-old male with a notable medical history of uncontrolled hypertension and heavy smoking, presented with a complex array of symptoms indicative of an advanced vascular condition. He reported a persistent ischaemic pain in his lower left limb, which he described as excruciating, with a severity level of 8 on a scale of 0 to 10. Physical examination revealed severely diminished circulation in the affected limb, coupled with ulceration and tissue loss. The association with high amputation and mortality rates, along with the markedly poor quality of life, underscores the urgency and gravity of this clinical presentation, necessitating prompt and comprehensive diagnostic evaluation and management.

Given the underlying risk factors and the established association of this condition with high amputation and mortality rates, as well as the substantial impact on quality of life, a timely and comprehensive diagnostic assessment is imperative to guide appropriate therapeutic interventions.
